Award.AwardTitle: A Comparison of Aerosol Organic Carbon Measurements and Models in the Free Troposphere at Mauna Loa Observatory (MLO)
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will continue and enhance an ongoing measurement program at Mauna Loa Observatory (MLO) to routinely collect and analyze aerosol filter samples for non-sea salt sulfate (NSS), nitrate, sodium, ammonium, and nitric acid by now adding semi-continuous measurements of organic aerosol mass (OM). Instrumentation acquired under this award will make operationally defined measurements of organic carbon (OC) at MLO where air characteristic of the free troposphere can routinely be sampled. In addition, a number of seasonal intensive field measurement campaigns will be conducted at MLO to characterize OM in with even greater detail. The behavior and variability of the OC/NSS ratio will be determined over several years and through collaboration with other groups the results will be compared with numerical simulations using a variety of models. Results from this study will lead to an improved understanding of the role of organic carbon compounds in tropospheric aerosol chemistry, and a better quantification of organic aerosol mass will enable more accurate representations of organic matter in model treatments. The broader impacts of this work include continuing a long-term heritage of highly climate relevant observations at MLO, producing important insights on how to better constrain chemical transport models and reduce uncertainties in climate model simulations, and providing research and educational opportunities for students at the University of Hawaii.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Technical Merit: One of the major factors that affect our climate is the fraction of incoming sunlight that is reflected back to space. Sunlight that is reflected away doesn’t add its heat to the Earth. Tiny particles in the air can reflect sunlight away, thereby reducing global warming. They also control how reflective clouds are, further affecting the solar heating of the Earth.

 

But how many airborne particles are there? Where do they come from? How big an effect do they have on climate change? These are the questions our project sought to answer. While there have been many studies of particles near the Earth’s surface, very few experiments have been done to identify particles several kilometers up. The Mauna Loa Observatory (MLO) is an ideal site for such high-altitude studies, because it is a well-instrumented facility with buildings and a sampling tower at 3.4 km altitude (about 11,000 ft). We have made a few particle measurements at MLO for almost 20 years, but this grant enabled us to also measure particles containing carbon.

 

These “organic” (not in the sense of organic food, but rather carbon-containing) particles behave differently from other particles. They are less likely to grow bigger by taking on water, for instance, than some of the ionic (electrically-charged) particles we could measure before this grant. We expected to find many more organic particles than ionic ones, since that is what we found during a brief aircraft study near Japan in 2001, at the same altitude. We were surprised, though to find that the organic particle amounts were much smaller at MLO. This tells us that sunlight breaks down many organic particles during the week or so it takes them to ride the winds from Asia to MLO. Computer simulations of climate must therefore include not only how many organic particles are emitted into the air by Asian sources, but also how rapidly these particles are destroyed by sunlight.

 

Broader Impacts: This will make climate models more realistic, so policymakers can make informed decisions about controlling climate change.
